text: CANADA — VISA / TEMPORARY RESIDENT (VISITOR) GUIDELINES (FULL TEXT) Purpose Guidance for applying for a Temporary Resident Visa (Visitor Visa) to Canada, covering who must apply, eligibility, documentation and procedural steps for visa officers and applicants. Eligibility Criteria Applicant must have a valid travel document (passport) and must be admissible to Canada. Applicant must satisfy the visa officer that they will leave Canada at the end of their authorized stay. Applicant must have sufficient funds to support themselves and any dependents during the visit (unless sponsored). Applicant must have no criminal inadmissibility issues and meet health requirements as applicable. Applicant must demonstrate ties to their home country (employment, family, property, studies) to establish intention to return. Documents Typically Required Completed application forms and instruction guide (Instruction Guide — Guide 5256 for visitor visa). Valid passport, photographs per specification, and application fees. Proof of funds (bank statements, sponsor letters). Travel itinerary, invitation letters, and any documents establishing purpose of visit. Police certificates or medical exam if requested. Notes and Special Cases Processing may vary by visa office; applicants applying on paper should consult instruction guides specific to their country. Biometric collection may be required. Electronic travel authorization rules and exemptions apply for certain nationalities; always check up-to-date IRCC pages. Key official guidance (source) IRCC: Guide 5256 — Applying for a visitor visa (Temporary Resident Visa)

Ireland’s visa policy Ireland distinguishes between short‑stay visas (type C, up to 90 days) and long‑stay visas (type D, more than 90 days) for non‑EU/EEA/Swiss and non‑UK nationals. Visa‑exempt nationals (for example many Annex II countries, US, etc.) can enter without a visa for short visits but must still respect immigration permission conditions at the border. Ireland is not part of Schengen; a Schengen visa does not allow entry to Ireland, and an Irish visa does not allow entry to Schengen countries. Who needs a visa Citizens of EU/EEA, Switzerland and the UK do not need a visa to enter Ireland, though they may still need to register for residence depending on length and purpose of stay. Many non‑EU countries are visa‑exempt for short stays, but large groups (including India, Pakistan, Nigeria, etc.) must obtain a visa even for tourism or short visits. Some nationalities are exempt from visa fees but not from the visa requirement itself. Short stay “C” visa (≤90 days) The standard short‑stay “C” visa covers tourism, visiting family/friends, business, short training or study (e.g., short English courses) for a maximum of 90 days. Applicants must show a valid reason for travel, proof of accommodation, full travel itinerary, travel/medical insurance, and sufficient funds without recourse to public funds. A key requirement is evidence of strong ties (family, social, economic) to the country of residence to show you will leave Ireland before your permission expires. Long stay “D” visa (>90 days) A long‑stay “D” visa is needed if you intend to study, work, join family, or otherwise remain in Ireland for more than 90 days. After arrival with a D visa, you must register locally with Immigration Service Delivery (ISD) or GNIB to get an Irish Residence Permit (IRP) and an immigration stamp (e.g., Stamp 1, 2, 3,

you intend to study, work, join family, or otherwise remain in Ireland for more than 90 days. After arrival with a D visa, you must register locally with Immigration Service Delivery (ISD) or GNIB to get an Irish Residence Permit (IRP) and an immigration stamp (e.g., Stamp 1, 2, 3, 4) that defines your rights to work, study, or access services. Different D‑visa categories (study, employment, family reunification, research, etc.) have tailored document and financial requirements. Student visa policies (including 2025 fund change) For long‑term study, you apply for a long‑term study D visa with a letter of acceptance from a recognised institution, proof of tuition payment (often full or at least €6,000), English‑language test scores, medical insurance, and explanations of study and career plans. From mid‑2025, financial requirements increased: students generally must now show at least about €12,000 in liquid, traceable funds for living costs, up from €10,000 under previous rules. Indian and other non‑EU students on a valid student permission can usually work part‑time during term and full‑time during scheduled breaks, and may access post‑study work routes (typically 1–2 years) before moving to an employment permit if eligible. Work and employment‑related policies Non‑EU nationals usually need an employment permit (e.g., Critical Skills or General Employment Permit) plus a corresponding D visa before travelling to take up work. Policy updates up to 2025 have expanded the list of eligible occupations (e.g., some social care and technical trades) and reduced the minimum period before changing employers from 12 to 9 months for first‑time permit holders. Spouses and partners of certain permit holders now have broader rights to work without their own employment permit, although some dependants must wait 12 months before relocating and others receive non‑work Stamp 3 permission. Visit, processing times, and documentation Tourist/visitor C visas typically require a completed online application, passport valid at least 6 months beyond intended stay, photos, fee payment, proof of funds, accommodation, travel plans, and letters explaining purpose and intention to return. Typical processing times for C tourist visas are in the range of about 15–25 working days, but can be longer if extra checks are needed or during busy seasons. Official ISD tables regularly publish which application dates are currently being processed for different visa types (tourism, study, employment, etc.), useful for planning. Immigration permission stamps and residence After entry, your passport is stamped with an immigration permission type (Stamp 1 for most workers, Stamp 2 for full‑time students, Stamp 3 for non‑working dependants, Stamp 4 for certain long‑term residents and family members, etc.). These stamps, plus the Irish Residence Permit card, govern what you can legally do in Ireland: work, study, start a business, or simply reside without work rights. Extensions or changes of status usually require applying to ISD with updated documents before your current permission expires.

Schengen visa rules allow stays of up to 90 days in any 180-day period across the 29 Schengen Area member states. Applicants must submit an application form, valid passport, ICAO- compliant photos, medical travel insurance, and proof of purpose, financial means, accommodation, and intention to return. Entry into the Schengen Area starts a 180-day counter, and overstaying is not allowed. The visa sticker specifies permitted days. Key Rules Visa validity: Maximum 90 days within any 180-day period; applies to the entire Schengen Area, not per country. Passport validity: Must be valid for at least 3 months beyond intended departure. Entry types: Single-entry: one entry only. Multiple-entry: repeated entries allowed, but stays must follow the 90/180 rule. Competent authority: Apply to the embassy/consulate of your main destination or the first- entry country if no main destination. Required Documents Completed Schengen visa application form Valid passport with minimum three months validity beyond departure date ICAO-standard passport photos Proof of Schengen medical travel insurance (covers medical emergencies, hospitalization, repatriation; minimum €30,000) Supporting documents for purpose of stay: Flight bookings Hotel bookings or accommodation proof Bank statements, payslips Proof of financial means Cover letter explaining purpose Evidence of intention to return Fingerprints are collected unless exempt Recent Changes for Indian Nationals Eligibility for 2-year multiple-entry visa requires at least two previously used Schengen visas in the last three years. After using a 2-year MEV, eligibility may extend to a 5-year multiple-entry visa. Visa validity cannot exceed passport expiry. Schengen Travel Rules (Dos) 1. Ensure proper validity Visa stays max 90 days in 180 days; cannot be exceeded. Invalid visa can lead to penalties or bans. 2. Carry essential documents Passport, insurance, accommodation proof, return ticket, and other required docs must be carried. 3. Respect local customs Understand local traditions; behave accordingly. New Visa Rules Summary Indians can receive 2-year Schengen visas. This can extend to 5-year multiple-entry visas. Allows multiple entries without needing new visas as long as passport validity supports it. FAQ Extract What is a Schengen visa? Allows travel across 29 Schengen countries with one visa. Meaning of first point of entry? The first Schengen country you will enter; responsible for issuing visa if it’s your main entry. How to apply? Apply at the relevant consulate or online; travel brokers can assist.

UNITED KINGDOM — VISA ELIGIBILITY GUIDELINES (FULL TEXT) Purpose This guidance covers short-term and standard visitor visas and explains the eligibility and suitability criteria UK Visas and Immigration uses when deciding applications. It also includes permitted activities, validity and evidentiary expectations. Eligibility Criteria Applicant must intend to visit the UK for a temporary period and leave at the end of the visit. Applicant must be able to do only permitted activities for that visa class (e.g., tourism, visiting, short business activities) and must not do work or study beyond what is permitted. Applicant must pay for their return or onward journey or demonstrate funds to do so. Applicant must be able to support and accommodate themselves for the duration of their stay without accessing public funds. Applicant must satisfy identity, suitability, and credibility checks — including whether they have previously breached UK immigration rules or been removed. Applicants who require a visa must apply online and attend a biometric appointment at a visa application centre. Documents Typically Required Valid passport (with sufficient validity) and previous passports if available. Completed online application and confirmation. Biometric enrolment (photo + fingerprints) at the visa centre. Proof of travel plans and funds: bank statements, payslips, sponsorship letters, accommodation details. Evidence of ties to home country: employment letter, family, property or study enrolment. Additional documents for specific visitor subcategories (eg academic visitor evidence, medical treatment letters, etc.). Notes and Special Cases There are several distinct visitor subcategories (Standard Visitor, Transit Visitor, Marriage/Civil Partnership Visitor, Academic Visitor) each with specific permitted activities and time limits. A visa does not guarantee entry — final admission is subject to border control. Some nationalities are visa-exempt; check nationality tables for requirements. Key official guidance (source) UK Visit guidance (Home Office).

US Visa Process 2025 for All Nationalities – Updated Rules & Timeline The US visa process is the official pathway that individuals from other countries must follow to legally enter the United States. It ensures that only qualified individuals with valid reasons for travel —such as tourism, education, business, employment, or immigration —are perm itted entry. In 2025, the system has become more digital, applicant -friendly, and streamlined, while still maintaining high -security standards to safeguard national interests. There are two primary visa categories under U.S. immigration law:  Non-Immigrant Visas (NIV): These are for individuals who plan to stay in the U.S. temporarily. Common types include B1/B2 for tourists and business visitors, F1 for students, and H1B for skilled workers.  Immigrant Visas (IV): These are issued to individuals seeking to live permanently in the United States, such as those sponsored by family members or employers, or those selected in the Diversity Visa (DV) Lottery. Updated Rules in the 2025 US Visa Process In 2025, the United States overhauled its visa process to make it faster, more secure, and easier to navigate. These updates apply to both non -immigrant and immigrant visa applicants. The U.S. government introduced new technology, expanded access to faster services, and removed outdated barriers, all while maintaining strict security standards. Applicants can now expect a more efficient experience with fewer delays and clearer communication. Digital Form Upgrades: Fill Forms Faster with Fewer Errors The U.S . Department of State upgraded the DS-160 and DS-260 application forms with smart digital features. Applicants can now benefit from real-time data validation , which highlights errors or missing fields instantly, helping them fix mistakes before submission. The new auto -save feature prevents data loss by saving progress continuously, which eliminates the frustration of starting over due to timeouts. By enabling digital signatures , the system also allows applicants to complete submissions without printing o r scanning, making the process more convenient and fully digital. These upgrades have improved form accuracy and increased approval rates for correctly submitted applications. Biometric Exp ansion: Strengthening Security t hrough Better Verification In 2025, U.S. immigration authorities expanded biometric requirements to include iris scans and facial recognition along with the existing fingerprinting process. These advanced measures now help officials verify identities more accurately and quickly. They also a llow U.S. agencies to cross -reference applicants against international security databases, which enhances border safety. By using more biometric data, the U.S. speeds up background checks while reducing identity fraud. Applicants now go through a more secu re yet faster screening process. Interview Waiver Expansion: Skip the Interview if You Qualify The U.S. expanded the visa interview waiver program to include more eligible applicants. If your visa expired within the last 48 months , you can now renew it wi thout attending an in -person interview . This applies to popular visa categories like B1/B2 (business/tourist) , F (student) , and H (work) visas. The updated rule reduces wait times at U.S. consulates and allows qualified applicants to complete their renewal by mailing in documents or using drop -box services. By waiving interviews for low -risk, returning applicants, consular offices can focus on new or complex cases, making the entire system more efficient. The time it takes to complete the US visa process in 2025 depends heavily on the visa type, your nationality, and how quickly you submit complete and correct information. Embassy backlogs, administrative processing, and seaso nal surges (like summer or academic intake periods) can all affect waiting times. Fortunately, the U.S. government has implemented automation in several visa processing stages to streamline timelines. Average Processing Times by Visa Type:  Tourist/Business Visas (B1/B2) : These typically take 2 to 6 weeks, including appointment scheduling, biometrics, and interview. In peak seasons, it may stretch to 8 weeks or more.  Student Visas (F1/M1) : Usually processed in 4 to 8 weeks. Early application is advised due to SEVIS activation and school semester start dates. Delays in I -20 issuance can also extend processing.  Work Visas (H1B, L1, O1) : These can take 3 to 6 months, depending on the type and whether you apply for regular or premium processing. Premium processing (available for a fee) reduces the timeline to 2 –4 weeks.  Immigrant Visas (Green Cards) : Processing ranges from 6 to 18 months.
